definition: gossip/hearsay/rumor

road/path/CL:條|条[tiao2],股[gu3]/principle/truth/morality/reason/skill/method/Dao (of Daoism)/to say/to speak/to talk/classifier for long thin things (rivers, cracks etc), barriers (walls, doors etc), questions (in an exam etc), commands, courses in a meal, steps in a process/(old) circuit (administrative division)
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
way/route/road
to persuade
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)

sentences.english: Will also descend the tunnel sees, always listen to than other people panic nervous Zhang Dao the way say well.
sentences.chinese: 也會下隧道去看，總比別人慌慌張張道聽途說的好。

sentences.english: Even just passing gossip and hearsay can prime your mind for illness with potent effect.
sentences.chinese: 哪怕只傳傳流言蜚語和道聽途說都能灌輸強烈影響。

sentences.english: Nevertheless, you are OK also these message regard as bru it or it is gossip.
sentences.chinese: 不過，你也可以將這些消息看做謠傳或是道聽途說。

sentences.english: They're just going by hearsay and duplicating what they think the pro's are using.
sentences.chinese: 他們只是去的道聽途說和重複表裏如一親的使用。

sentences.english: The attorney for the defense challenged the evidence as hearsay.
sentences.chinese: 被告辯護律師駁斥該證據爲道聽途說。

sentences.english: You must have heard it through the grapevine.
It's nothing more than to defend the historical memory.
sentences.chinese: 太史公道聽途說，無非是爲了捍衛歷史的記憶。

sentences.english: Believe not whatever you see nor half what you hear.
sentences.chinese: 雖眼見亦不能全信，道聽途說更不足信。

sentences.english: Gossip is what no one claims to like, but everybody enjoys.
sentences.chinese: 沒有人自稱喜歡道聽途說，但人人都樂此不倦。

definition: to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to disdain as beneath contempt (idiom)
lit. first impression is strongest
complete nonsense (idiom)
to force someone to do something
to tell the truth/to tell it as it is
to make a story or theory consistent/to give a plausible explanation/to plug the holes in one's story
to shoot without aim (idiom); fig. to speak without thinking/firing blindly/to shoot in the air/a shot in the dark
plain/clear/obvious
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
to invent crazy nonsense/to cook up (excuses)/to talk at random/wild babble
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
not one good point/everything about it is wrong
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
lit. to put Zhang's hat on Li's head/to attribute sth to the wrong person (idiom)/to confuse one thing with another
